title: Z axis anti backlash for Prusa i3 Shorter Version

description.text:
I found the design from Tech2C very useful and easy to install.

But my printer still has some trouble with long and thin parts, so I made a shorter version.
I also added chamfer on the nut top in order to fit easier. I also made the nut a little bit taller.

Comments and critics are welcome.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3 Metal Frame

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40% 3D HoneyComb

Notes:

Printed in ABS

BOM
  • 2 x Parts
  • 4 x M5 nuts
  • 2 x Spring
  • Some ball bearing grease (optional)
Assembly
  1. Place a nut on the Rod
  2. Place the spring
  3. Place the other nut so the spring is held between the nuts
  4. Put some grease over the spring
  5. Insert the nuts on the printed part

I recommend to put grease on between the two nuts, so it will lubricate the rod as it travels.
Designed Solidworks 2014

author: TheSmilingXenomorph

print_settings.Notes:: If you have a better printer, try to drive down the resolution to smaller values.  I'm curious how small this can get.

description.text:
This is an OpenSCAD library for generating 3D prints of tightly woven fabrics. I was inspired by the many chainmail patterns I saw on here, and started wondering what it would take to generate a woven fabric pattern. There are three weave patterns I came up with. One is a flat classic fabric weave with sinusoidal waves in the z direction. The second is a crossed pattern of right handed and left-handed helices where each helix always cross the others at a right angle. The third pattern has interlocking helices traveling only in the x direction, resulting in a tightly woven fabric pattern that flexes freely in the y direction without even bending the plastic. (This last pattern might work very well for bracelets, as one example.)

I've enabled the Customizer feature for creating fabric samples right here. But probably for most interesting uses this will be a component of other designs. The useful API functions for use in your own OpenSCAD routines are as follows:

/ Creates a flat fabric weave with overall fabric dimensions of x_len by
// y_len. Each thread has a diameter of diam, and the threads print with a
// minimum distance between each other of approximately clearance.
module MakeFlatFabric(x_len, y_len, diam, clearance)

// Creates a helical/counterhelical fabric weave with overall fabric dimensions
// of x_len by y_len. Each thread has a diameter of diam, and the threads
// print with a minimum distance between each other of approximately clearance.
module MakeHelicalFabric(x_len, y_len, diam, clearance)

// Creates an interlocking x-oriented helical weave with overall fabric
// dimensions of x_len by y_len. Each thread has a diameter of diam, and the
// threads print with a minimum distance between each other of approximately
// clearance. This pattern naturally flexes and stretches well in the y
// direction as generated, while being more rigid in the x direction.
module MakeYFlexFabric(x_len, y_len, diam, clearance)

Printer:

HICTOP 3DP-11

Resolution:

0.5mm x&y, 0.2mm z

Notes:

Initial adhesion is very critical as the print starts as just an array of dots for the lowest layer. I recommend calibrating your initial z offset well, and then applying a fresh layer of adhesive (e.g. glue stick) shortly before the print.

If you have trouble printing a small weave pattern, try calibrating your extrusion rate for line thickness, or adjust the temperature and cooling. You will also need to make sure your retraction settings are adequate as these patterns can retract hundreds of times per print even for a small piece of fabric.

If you have a better printer, try to drive down the resolution to smaller values. I'm curious how small this can get.

I couldn't figure out how to create exactly the shapes I needed using any of the pre-built routines in OpenSCAD, so I had to break out some vector math and generate each thread as a custom polyhedron. The best way I could think of to do this was functionally with tail recursion to generate all the points and faces. This ended up running much faster than I anticipated, and produced a pretty nice result in a relatively short (but dense) stretch of code.

comments.text:
Nice project. I did no went deep in your code but here are two suggestions:
a) to get a more regular Helical Fabric you should consider to add translate([-diam/2,diam/2, 0]) before MakeXThreads inside MakeHelicalFabric;
b) I think you could save a lot of code by using sweep.scad and possibly would avoid recursions, though tail recursion elimination is fast.
comments.author: RoCMP

comments.text: Yes, it seems you're correct.  That translation centers the threads better.  While it ends up identical after printing, since the threads move freely, your fix improves the printing tolerances (which enables printing tighter weaves).  I updated the posted .scad file to include this fix.  Thanks.
comments.author: RoCMP

description.text: I remixed this design to be able to fit over 1/2" pine dowels used on my Flitetest Electrohub. They fit great and seem like they'll be quite strong. They use a standard 25mm x 25mm mounting hole spacing.

Printer:

Davinci 1.0a with Repetier

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

50% or higher

Notes:

These fit the dowels very tightly. Depending on your dowel, you may have to shave or sand down the end to slide these over the end. A standard M3 screw passes through the mount and the arm to secure it. Make sure you print at a high enough temperature to get good layer adhesion as there is direct stress on the layer bond and that is the most likely place for it to break. A zip tie around the mount could be used as a precaution if you feel it is necessary.

These also extend the arm length a bit which, depending on your design, may allow for slightly larger props.

comments.author: luqui82

comments.text: The physical phenomenon you are looking to use is the venturi effect. From your cross section shot, I think you need to restrict the main airflow a little more to increase the velocity. The shaped chamber within the body looks like a nice generator of turbulence, which you do not want. Adding thin veins will break up the larger vortices (and aid in supporting the print). All in all, a nice project that I have been wanting to have a hand in. If I can help in any way, just ask and I will try to help.
comments.author: inle_rah

comments.text: Thanks for the advice. Do you have any tips on the best impeller shape? I've tried 3 different designs and they were all quite useless. Would you recommend veins in the top half as well as the bottom?
comments.author: inle_rah

comments.text: Hey I like the no-supports approach you've taken with your design. I think you might be having trouble because the opening on the inside of the ring might be too large. I'm not an aerospace engineer, but it on another famous blade-less fan design it seems that the air is accelerated by a reduction in cross sectional area, causing it to "stick" to the airfoil profile on the way out. Image Herehttp://i.imgur.com/sLiVZ9x.jpg....

Inventor

This is a simple Filament guide for the Wanhao i3. I recently purchased one of these printers for my daughter and another for myself. There is a filament guide that is similar to this one already on Thingiverse. I even downloaded it and tried to use that one. But it did not work for me. It kept jumping off of the printer.

So I designed this one from the ground up. It has longer legs and you have to thread it before inserting the filament into the extruder. But it seems like it will stay in place.

The one in the photo was printed on the Wanhao i3 V2.1 Printer with ABS filament. No supports needed. However, I did use a raft.

The STL and 123D Design files are here.
The guide simply sits on the top rail of the printer. It will slide back and forth under the filament spool.

comments.text: Thank you for providing this guide, Lloyd.  I took your model and made a 2mm slit along the centerline of the top of the cylinder so that the filament doesn't need to be threaded.  (The first attempt I made put the slit off to one side and I got to witness how printing in mid-air works (or, more precisely, doesn't work).  :)

Not a lot of people with my last name, but might be a few others out there with the same last name who may want it.

Regular

20%

Notes:

Set X-hop to 0.75mm
Scale to whatever size you like.
Printed in Dark Blue nGen filament.

Cleanup

Minimal cleanup needed, just took off a few bumps/high spots with an X-acto knife.

Designed this using SketchUp. Installed Lobster font, extruded letters. Created a base to tie the bottom letters together so the sign would stay as one piece. Needed to also create a bit of filler to attach the dot over the 'i'. Also raised the letters above the base so they could be cleanly seen, also raised every other letter so the serifs on the letters were more distinct and play with the shadows you'll see when looking at the printed object.

author: eried

description.text: In this activity students first learn about modular arithmetic. They will first discover what the possible remainders of a whole number look like and then create a 3D model of a clock with the remainders of a chosen number value. Using this model students will work through some problems finding remainders and then be introduced to the a≡b (mod n) notation.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

standard

Infill:

10%

Students can be given the blank clock template and then just add numbers to it or you can have students design their own clock. This design is fairly easy to make. For the spinner I made the diameter of the open circle a little bigger than the diameter of the cylinder it went around (9.6 mm and 9 mm, respectively). For the spinner I used a cylinder with diameter 15.1mm and then created a cylinder hole in the center with diameter 9.6 mm.
CCSS

In this activity students first learn about modular arithmetic. They will first discover what the possible remainders of a whole number look like and then create a 3D model of a clock with the remainders of a chosen number value. Using this model students will work through some problems finding remainders and then be introduced to the a≡b (mod n) notation. Objectives From this activity students will learn:
That the remainders of a number n go from 0 to n-1.
How to find reminders when any number is divided by n
The congruent notation for modular arithmetic Audiences This topic is not explicitly listed as part of the Common Core Standards. It can be done at any point after students know how to divide and find remainders. The last problem on the worksheet is at a high school level, but that question can easily be dropped to make this activity more suitable for younger students. I plan to use this activity in a college level number theory course. Even though the skill level is very low, I think it will allow students to get a better grasp of what it means for two numbers to be congruent in mod n, and having the physical 3D model will help make the definition more concrete and memorable. Skills Learned CCSS.Math.Practice.MP4 Model with mathematics.
CCSS.Math.Practice.MP5 Use appropriate tools strategically.
CCSS.Math.Practice.MP7 Look for and make use of structure.

For this activity students will work in groups. They will be given the worksheet. The worksheet is self-guided and has all the information they need on it, but you may choose to go over parts of it together. Day 1 gives some quick explorations of remainders and leads to discovering that the possible remainders when dividing by a number n is 0 to n-1. Then students will design and print a clock face. The printing can be completed overnight. On the second day students use their clocks to practice finding remainders. They then learn the congruent notation and do practice problems using it.
This activity is estimated to take 2 days. The worksheet is split up into the two different days.

The only background knowledge students need is to be able to divide whole numbers and find the remainder when dividing. An introduction to Algebra may be useful too since the last problems use x as an unknown to solve for.

By completing this project students will have made the clock and know how to tell when two numbers are congruent in mod n. If you choose to go over the answers together rather than have students hand in their worksheets this can be treated as an informal assessment or part of a participation grade. If you would like to grade this activity a sample rubric is below:
Day 1 (points)
Got remainders correct on clock for chosen n value (1)
Participated in answering worksheet questions (1)
Day 2
1 Correctly answered each part (a-d) (1 each, 4 total)
2 Used the new notation correctly (1)
3 Correctly answered each part (a-c) (1 each, 3 total)
Total 10

description.text:
UPDATE: 9/22/2106
I replaced all the stage one segment files

UPDATE: 8/1/2016
I have corrected some issues i noticed while doing a test print.

  1. Hinge area on the landing legs has been revised
  2. grid fins are more accurate now, not sure how they will print yet
  3. corrected some geometry issues on the engines so they will hopefully print better in the v002 file
  4. adjusted some of the tubes and pipes based on some better reference photos I found.

I just finished modeling this. I am currently test printing it.
I am continuing to update the model and refine it. If you have modeled a piece of this rocket and would like to share it I would love to keep improving this model.
I have a couple project ideas for using this rocket after i get the mesh cleaned up and printing smooth and reliably.

Unless you print it very large there are likely a lot of details that wont show up in the print.
I took some liberties here and there with the model to add detail but isnt exactly the same as the rocket.
Also every mission the rocket seems to be slightly different in some detail here or there.
I will keep this updated as I slice the model up and to address issues i notice while I print this.

Also its waaaay over sized in the stl file, just scale it down to whatever size you want.

Update to the previous version to allow for printing in PLA. I've also included 3 different 'front' pieces, to allow for printers with different tolerances. The pitot tube is 4mm in diameter, so there is a front with 0.1mm tolerance (what I use on my Up Mini), 0.3mm tolerance and 0.5mm tolerance. Update:
base v1.9 has been added, which features protrusions that will prevent the pitot tube being pushed into the back wall, and kinking or cutting the tubing. This was suggested by Lorenz Meier. The downside is that it's more difficult to feed the tube through, so I've kept the previous version availible.

Hi apnolan, unfortunately it seems that this is a bit of a difficult part to print depending on your printer. I'm working on simplifying it, but have had a severe shortage of time recently, which is why progress has stalled.
I have consistent results on an UP Mini by printing in ABS with 200um layer height and printing the nose section with supports. The trick is to print the part with the 45° seams flat on the print bed. This is what the arrangement looks like in the Up software: http://api.ning.com/files/4MXCALxsrL0agB3hB06k9fTeA9B8zf203OC4jYqFeowmeXNQyV36fvo9P6IwdZGFp6dFy9*4EzQTpCRyhs45ORPNTvGHA0LA/ScreenShot20140417at3.52.09pm.pnghttp://api.ning.com/files/4MXC...

title: CMSS - Customizable Modular Storage System - Door hinge

description.text:
This is modular system for making a shelfs.
Main part is this connector.
It allows you to connect plates of cardboard or some other material, glass, plexiglass etc.
Of course, everything is customizable. We reccomend to remember or write down dimensions for printing other parts. For example - door hinge part need same dimensions as connector to fit together
More from this system:

main connector http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1369482
door handle http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1693253

Included stl is for desk with thickness 5mm

Sponsor MakersLab creation of other models.
www.makerslab.cz
BTC addresses - 1TXcHQUt13P2veyDHeYDz7cciv47K4Coe
paypal addresses - [email protected]

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3, Rebelix

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.252

What do you need:
  • printed parts
  • desks made of cardboard, glass, plexiglass etc
  • pieces of filament to secure desks
  • lighter or source of high temperatures to heat pieces of filament securing desks
Getting everythig together:
  • Think about a shape you want to build
  • Print connectors and other parts customized just for your thickness of desks, and make sure they're strong enought to hold them (for glass desk you should rather use thicker connectors, etc.)
  • Put desks in connecotrs and other parts
  • Use lighter to make nail shape using piece of filament long enought to go through the desk and connector
  • Put nail shaped pieces into every hole in construction.

You are done! :-)

We were thinking about some shelf or a storage system that we need in Makerslab. At first we wanted make fully printable modular shelves. But we found it hard to make piece which would easily print and do not waste material... So here is system using not only printed parts. mainly it uses cardboards, because design in Makerslab and Paralelní polis is made out of carboard.

description.text:
There are not a lot of functional prints for women on Thingiverse so I thought it's a good area to try and make a contribution.The only tampon holder on Thingiverse is described as a "joke" :-/ I know the Maker community is very conservative but these are essential items that almost all women use. So it seemed to me we should have at least one here.

This is not the most space efficient design ever, but it's better than your tampons falling out of that flimsy box and tumbling around in the bottom of your bag. It's also a whole lot of fun to load up like an action heroine when feeling otherwise blah. You can even use it with one hand- leaving the other hand free to fight off villains! Really, really inconsiderate villains with terrible timing haha...

The magazine fits six OB Pro Comfort "Normal", or any 13mm x 52mm tampons. It should scale cleanly to fit any tampon the same approximate shape. The TinkerCAD model is here it you'd like to add text or decorations to it: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/gnOJgQYpBFs-tampon-magazine

The spring slides into the bottom plate. That assembly then gets inserted in the magazine and secured with a little superglue. I use superglue and PLA on almost all my prints and it works great, just make sure there's a good fit with no gaps and you only use a tiny tiny bit.

I made a short YouTube video showing my 3D printing workflow and instructions for assembling this print: https://youtu.be/ugxOl6tMnM4 It's my first build video and I'm a bit awkward so I'm not sure how useful it will be.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Two shells, four top and four bottom layers seems to work ok.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ugxOl6tMnM4" ></iframe>

title: PINBALL
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
PINBALL

A game that can be printed and you can add micro:bit or arduino to program the switches in the game.

Programming can be made easy or difficult depending on the grade you're in.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

It's printed on a opiliones delta printer with pla filament of the brand by ctrl design.
some parts need support.

PINBALL

The PINBALL is designed in sketchup 2016. The dimensions are based on a print bed of 300mm by 300mm. I add an mdf board so the print time is shorter en de surface for the ball is smother.

see the video how to put it all together

for the arduino you can design and print your own score board. for the micro:bit the dimensions are all the same so there for the score board is in the print files.

PINBALL

PINBALL

Pinball 3d print for micro:bit and arduino.

Overvieuw and Background:

By printing and programming pinball you will learn how to program, to print 3d parts, and how a circuit works.

Objectives:

Students learn how to use a 3D printer to print parts and to put that together. Students also learn how to make a switch and control it via Arduino and micro:bit. Learning programming the Arduino and micro: bit is the main learning process.

Audience:

The great thing about pinball is that it can be worked with from a young age. Because you can make simple programs with Arduino and micro:bit. At the age of 8 the teacher can print all the parts and put it together so that the studens only have to program. For the older students it can be made more difficult by complex projects and put everything together themselves.

Subjects:

pinball is an project that can be used in science, technology and math.

Skills Learned:

skills that you learn is to work together, spatial awareness, programming, design, 3D printing, cognitive and more. All depending on the difficulty of the project you’re programming.

Lesson / Activity:

The great thing about pinball is that you can go with it in many ways.

example:
the teacher print everything out and the student put it all together.

teacher and student discuss a programming assignment.

student performs programming and test it.

The teacher and students can decide together how difficult they make it. By keeping it simple it can take about 1 hour but if the students are going to do everything themselves then they may need a week.

There are endless possibilities to what students and educators can do with this project.
Duration:

The great thing about pinball is that it can take 1 hour ore almost a week.
All depending on how complex you will make the programming.

Preparation:

The programming of micro:bit and arduino are for simple and difficult programs. So you do not need any experience in programming. The fun part is that you can print the parts and put it together and start programming. You can start simple and make it during the year more difficult.

References:

https://www.arduino.cc/
https://www.microbit.co.uk/

Rubric and Assets:

I think that the final score is up to the teacher. Teacher and students can discus in front of the project what they should achieve and how its grated.

  • Looks of the 3d print parts
  • Color choice
  • Programming skills
  • Explanation of the programing done
  • ……

Handouts & Assets:

The link of how to put the printed parts together.

https://youtu.be/61XnCHkE1M8

title: Sky Hero Little Spyder RGB LED Mount

description.text:
This is a very clean and functional RGB LED Holder which allows a clean installation of RGB LEDs at the arms of X4 little spyders.

It fits to the underside of the original little spyder motor mounts. The power cables can be routed inside the arms so that the installation is very clean.

It allows the installation of 30mm diameter rgb leds (I used the matek 12V ones).

The printed part can be screwed to the original motor mounts. The LED itself can be glued with some small spots of glue into the printed part.

description.text:
This is a camera holder designed to fit into the camera slots of the Armattan X155 Morphite FPV cage.
The holder is designed for cheap 15x15mm CCTV cameras such as the Aomway HD mini 600TVL or the Eachine 700TVL.
Make sure to pick the right file for printing because some cameras have their wires come out at the bottom whereas others exit sideways. There is also room for the microphone if your camera has one.

When built in the FPV cage it fits snuggly, but you will still be able to adjust the tilt angle of the camera.

How to make:

  • Print the correct mount
  • Remove the plastic tube from which the wires exit the camera, be careful not to damage the wiring.
  • Remove lens and install the camera inside the mount.
  • Fixate the lens with two drops of hotglue on either side of the camera.
  • Mount the lens and adjust focus.

The original OpenSCAD files are provided to allow for customisation.

print_settings.Notes:: Also use an hard material, PLA is good as well but it will strip easily. See below for the workaround!

description.text:
While disassembling a Nespresso coffee machine I got stuck at removing the base's screws: their head is plainly oval, making it quite difficult to unscrew them.

Some of them are recessed of a few millimiters in my machine, but others of a few centimeters; it was impossible to remove the deeper ones with some pliers as I did for the others; to have the right tool for the job you have to either be a Nespresso repair shop or buy it online for around $10.

So I measured one of the already removed screws and sketched this printable bit, adding an optional handle groove as a Customizer option.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Kossel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Be sure to have enough infill around the screw socket or it will strip at the first try.

Also use an hard material, PLA is good as well but it will strip easily. See below for the workaround!

Be sure that the print has cooled down before removing it! It might be easy to deform such a small hole, and the maximum precision is needed to make the tool work without modifications.

If you find the hole to be too tight, either enlarge the margin via the Customizer or use the trick I prefer, since using a bigger margin might make the socket strip more easily:

  • Remove one of the screws on your machine using some pliers. Take your time to do this and be patient, as it will save you a lot of time further on.
  • Heat the head of the screw with a lighter until it's hot enough to be able to melt the material you printed the bit with. In this case less is better: you can always heat the screw up some more if it isn't hot enough, but you'll have to reprint the bit if you melt it too much.
  • Rotate the screw to match the socket in the bit as close as possible, and gently press it down in it. This way the socket will melt slightly around the head of the screw and will gain a tighter grip.
  • Let the assemble cool down and remove the screw as gently as possible.

The bit will now fit better, if it gets stripped just repeat the process.

title: BCN3D MOVEO - A fully OpenSource 3D printed Robot Arm

description.text:
BCN3D Technologies (https://twitter.com/bcn3dtech) keeps taking important steps in order to achieve his goal of bringing the digital manufacturing technology to everyone. In this occasion we are presenting the BCN3D Moveo, a robotic arm design from scratch and developed by our engineers in collaboration with the Departament d’Ensenyament from the Generalitat de Catalunya. Its structure is fully printed using additive manufacturing technologies and its electronics are controlled by the software Arduino. It has a Marlin based firmware developed for robot arms with steppers by Zortrax. The BCN3D Moveo has 5 axis.

Moveo, fully functional nowadays, has been born, as all the BCN3D Technologies products, with an open and educational wish.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XSY0kieEL8A

As we have done with all our developed products, the BCN3D Moveo files will be available for everyone. Thanks to the platform Github, a website where users around the world share their designs, anyone will be able to obtain all the necessary information in order to assemble his own BCN3D Moveo at home.

Nevertheless, BCN3D will fee all the Moveo know how on our Github account, as we have been doing with all the BCN3D Technologies products. Thus, the users will be able to find the bill of material (BOM), where all the needed components for the assembling of the arm come detailed, as the CAD designs, so anyone will be able to modify the BCN3D Moveo design as they wish.

Furthermore, the Github users will find the STL files for the structure printing and the assembling, fine tuning and firmware upload manuals, which will be available both in English and Spanish.

Download the BCN3D Moveo CAD files, the STL files, the assembly and user manual and the Bill of Materials on our Github: https://github.com/BCN3D

Read the full article: https://www.bcn3dtechnologies.com/en/bcn3d-moveo-the-future-of-learning/

Thanks to this project motivated by the Departament d’Ensenyament and developed by BCN3D Technologies everyone will be able to fabricate their own robotic arm at home, no highly technical knowledge needed. Therefore, we encourage you to fabricate the BCN3D Moveo and share the results on the social networks using the hashtag #BCN3DMoveo.

You can also follow us through our social media channels in order to get more information about us:

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/bcn3dtech/
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/bcn3dtechnologies/
Twitter: https://twitter.com/bcn3dtech

author: magonegro

title: Stabilo Stand (pen holder)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This simple design is based on the idea of contrast in color and material. The aluminum sandwich material features a white surface, metallic and black edges and gives a great contrast to the foot made from two layers of stained beech plywood. The parts are mounted with 40 mm counter sunk stainless steel Allen screws and nuts size M4.

Creating hexagonal holes in the upper part was more a funny idea, because the stand was made for use with Stabilo Point 88 pens which have a hexagonal shaft.

The build was done on a desktop cnc-machine from Stepcraft from 6.5 mm beech plywood, 2 mm Aludibond (aluminum compound material) using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute for the wood and a two-edged 1.4 mm flute for the aluminum.

Keep in mind that the "build stl" is meant for three dimensional viewing only.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.
I did differ from my sketch in the means of the material.

description.text:
I made a crude mount for my Nexus 5X, so I can bike around and catch 'em all.
The three parts bolt together with five 4mm X 20mm hex bolts, since I had those around.
But the bolt for the pivot is a squeze, would recommend one thats 25mm long for that.

It's meant to mount in the middle of your handle bars with a couple of zip ties.

$1 Zipties holding $400 worth of phone, because reasons.

Please note that this still has to be tested! All the measurements were done basing on the hotend's specifications.

Hi!

This is a generator for 2D subdivided surfaces

An old script made with Processing (http://www.processing.org) a few years ago, now adapted to Openscad.

This thing was the precursor of Futuristic Citybuider (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1680965) and follows a similar algorithm but now in 2D

You can generate rectangles, circles or polygons with different sizes and subdivision patterns in customizer.

I'm using in combination with Polygon bases and frames (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1693462) to make some boxes and pencil-cases.

Also you can use it for decoration, bracelets (blendig with warm water) or what you imagine.

Includes some STL files and some ZIPs with even more STLs

Hope you enjoy it
Have fun!

title: Racing Boat FTo11 3D Print improvements & Replacements
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hello friends, this time I want to start this Thing with some improvements & Repalcements for my FT011 (will be dificult because this boat comes really full tunned) but im shure we can 3d print some parts really usefull for this boat.

I would love to help me improve even more, with new ideas modifications or spare parts whatever you imagine..

and here I leave the set of we have all really done and other are cooking...
3d Printed imprpvements:
Gopro camera support for the Racing Boat.
waterproof ESC & reciver box.

and here I leave one set of things for future or inspiration for improve the boat
3d Printed ideas :
Trailer for the boat
internal support for intal a second battery & extend the play time
Add some extra weigt to the boat
custom flaps for better grip
spare clips parts for helmet case
Realistic Boat Stands
Led light Ip Protection

if someone has done or plan to do some design that can fit with the boat, I'll print it in 3D with pleasure.

here you can see one video desasambling proces, ggo for imagine new 3D parts
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eu0hKZMamUQ

why a boat?? ahah, is summer in my country , hot, hot , i thing is perfect for have a bit fun with some friends at beach.. And finaly it's here ! already !! , time to Tuning a boat race!!

At the moment I have these improvements, go adding new, so as i go building.
But with time , is shure im foinf to need some spares for this mashine. LIke broken parts or internal thing.

Please feel free to live a coment with any other improvement you think can be cool for this boat!

first let me talk a bit about my FT01 1 Racing boat , then you have a better idea about all the components and will be easy imagine new things for the boat..

Well, as probaly lots of you, I had never seen one live before, if it is true I was looking for information on the internet, but i need to say ,this boat in person looks AMAZING!! much more cool than in the fotos.

If a picture is worth a thousand words, a video is worth ten thousand !! have a look!

After all, this ship is an evolution of the FT line of Fei-Lun model, being a very affordable price for their boat, the config and components are absolutely cool, let me show you some fotos of it..

3 words,, Fast, very fast ,, all gas to be even too well controlled in a sea wave. But is funny to drive.

One thing I love about this set is that it comes absolutely everything you need to start from the first minute to have fun. you just have to buy batteries for the transmiter control (AA batterys) and after a good charge the boat battery add some of the improvements we made for this boat, you're ready to play.

*Imagine a FVP Remote control fot it? waaa! that would be amazing!

wen take the boat out of the box for firs time guive me a big surprise, a boat 65cm long which is robust and strong note and with a very Racing sport look .. The control slightly less finished the ship, but then speak better of him.

The feeling is weighs is more than one kilo (without battery) certainly is light for such a powerful engine of 14V! motor, servo electronics and all the components are protected by a double layer of water approved helmet.

The infer housing, has 5 points along with a rubber grip to seal. A second trim helmet protects the whole of the water inlet.

*I belive, lots of this components are easy to Break, i will go desing some spare , like the opne close clips from the helmet.. ans other ones..

it have a modern and agresive line. Mention this carbon fiber body (painted) fits very successful for this model.

May be one Thing improvement can be only estetic add?
we need to work on that!

One thing I take my attention on this boat is that in other cases, if the boat is not in the water does not turn on (for security) Well, this, it does !! once you've connected the battery and turning the station beware of the gas and brake, because activate the propellers at full speed.

The first time i throw into the water and see the great power of this engine , defnly is not just a toy. after the first 2 minits on the sea, feels really confortables to drive , and is imposible hold the temptation of open full trottle xDD

like one torpedo!

MAybe we can 3Dprint some Thing for guive better stabilzation at hig Speeds??
New ideas hare Welcome!

It has reverse direction, although to be honest, it's pretty dificult to control in reverse.
It is a boat that likes to go fast and zig zag. Nervous, an arrow in the water.

getting first touch conclusion.. this boat is amazing, fast and cheap! - Perfect for start with RC and NOT BE AFRAID TO MOD IT WITH YOUR 3D Print improvements.

Now for the more interested readers of this project I will have a look to some more technical details of this black beast.

Auto Flipping system! *is posible improve?

what is this?? ahah this is a cool thing.
Well, it's a super useful, if for example after a big jump, the boat has been upside down in the water. Well, with a combination of gas and brake on the remote transmitter, the boat turns around and you can continue surfing.

what motor is fitted in?

oook ,, this black beas have one 2822 outrunner carries motor integrated into the hull boat is brushless motor by the way, and as you know, a brushless motor is translated into better performance and less maintenance.
All the power is transfered to the propeller from a metal transmission, which ensures a strong and steady to the boat's propeller driven.


Liquid refrigeration system! *is posible to improve?

this left me flip a bit ,, cooling liquid motor and ESC is great solution, since the ESC 65A as the engine at extremely high speeds, they generate a lot of heat.
The system works by sucking water through the tube located at the helm (see foto), the water passes through the tubes, cooling the electronic components and out the side of the boat. Very cool! & loke the real boats.


Rudder

It is made of resistant plastic, it is moved by a metal part (guide) that is hooked to a small servo. Beside the possibility of some adjustment in the queue.
Thanks to the side flaps and the rear metal flaps (all easily adjustable mind) a pretty good boat control is achieved.


The transmitter: *is posible to improve?

This one, in my opinion come with less finish than the boat. yes, makes its function, it is a very basic command of two channels, works in the 2.4GHz frequency and can run more ships together without any interference problem. but i miss a bit more professional controller for it..

it can control the Raving Boat up to 150M distance with no problems.
have an on of button , has a calibration helm from the control and also the range of rotation. Gas controls and reverse gear, feels precise, and is easy to control the gas of the boat.

is fine and precise control provided (perhaps too powerful reverse) guess that will be necessary for self Fplipped funktion.. there are times that to turn aside, it is necessary to increase the speed, otherwise the radius rotation may be wider than desired.


GoPro camera support - *Improvement for First person Recording

To record in first person the boat have made this bracket, easily adjustable with electrical tape, I'm thinking the day of the test, and I think I'll also add a small buoy or something to the camera. At least until you confirm 100% that resists boat speeds. Click here to have a closer look.

camera support
camera support
camera support

Power it with 14,8V !!

what feeds the beast alive is a 14.8V battery 2200 mah, 30c and S4 model.
(it come with Carger 4S ready) I think increasing slightly to a stack with more mha, you could gain a little more fun time. Currently with battery 2200, I have come for a walk with the boat, 10 minutes.

Also , i,m planing to add a second battery in paralel, intalled with a special 3d printed support and joint two of this batteries.


Conclusions and feelings with my new boat ,,
It is a good boat to worry more about play than care about maintenance.
It comes full assembled and ready for tune up with the 3d print parts, perfect for beginners in the RC boat and 3d printing world.
is mantinaince free. Is big & fast also have a really cool look..

Here I leave the set of pieces that brought me the kit.
1x boat FT011
1x 2.4GHz Transmitter (Requires 6x "AA" batteries)
1x 4S lipo charger
1x 14.8V 2200mAh 30C Lithium Polymer battery
1x Plastic display stand
1x Rubber bumper nosecone
2x Propeller (spares)
1x Bag of accessories (3x Spare props, 2x Hex nuts, 1x Prop removal tool, 1x Waterproof marine grease, 1x Hex drive)
where do i get it?
where to find original spares?

and if you have any doubt i can help with will doit with pleasure.
thanks for watching

This is free version of 3d printed MyoTriton project. (http://myotriton.com)
Using this files you could print completed hand and use it in prosthetics or to use like a part of robot or etc.

To collect full hand you should print:

  • Worm_v.3.3.0.STL - x5
  • Thumb_v.3.3.0.STL - x1
  • Link_v.3.3.0.STL - x4
  • Housing_v.3.3.0.STL - x4
  • Housing thumb_v.3.3.0.STL - x1
  • Hand_upper_cover_v3.3.0.STL - x1
  • Hand_buttom_cover_v.3.3.0.STL - x1
  • Finger_middle_part_v.3.3.0.STL - x4
  • Finger_first_part_v.3.3.0.STL - x4
  • Clamp_v.3.3.0.STL - x1

Besides these 3d printed parts you will need to buy additional devices:

  • Arduino Nano - x1
  • LiPo battery 1500mAh 7.4v - x1
  • Servo Mg995 or Mg996r (only with circle metal potentiometer) - x5
  • DC 6V 200RPM Mini Electric Metal Gear Motor Gearwheel N20 - x5
  • Bearings 3х6х2 - x10
  • Bearings 5х11x3 - x5
  • Hobnail 2mm diameter ~ x5
  • Hobnail 3mm diameter ~ x5

Printer:

Flashforge Dreamer

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

60%

This is the completed prototype of MyoTriton prosthetic hand. Worm before treatment (Worm_v.3.3.0.STL) Worm after treatment (Worm_v.3.3.0.STL) Potentiometer from the servo installed in the Housing_v.3.3.0.STL. You need to change DC motor How the single finger works. Chip from the servo connected to the new DC motor One of completed finger Worm_v.3.3.0.STL with bearing 3х6х2 and Bearings 5х11x3 Completed body for finger: Housing_v.3.3.0.STL + Worm_v.3.3.0.STL with bearing 3х6х2 and Bearings 5х11x3 Pin that was made from Hobnail 2mm diameter. You should use it to connect Finger_first_part_v.3.3.0.STL + Link_v.3.3.0.STL. This pin is also using to connect Link_v.3.3.0.STL and Housing_v.3.3.0.STL Pin that was made from Hobnail 2mm diameter. You should use it to connect Finger_first_part_v.3.3.0.STL + Finger_middle_part_v.3.3.0.STL

title: Bed bottle holder for kids beds

description.text:
My kids just can't go to bed without a small water bottle in can they will be thirsty in the middle of the night, until recently the bottles were place on the floor near the bed - but we just got them a bunk bed and placing the bottle on the floor is no longer an option

This model (unlike any of my previous models) is optimized for a 1mm nozzle because it seems like a good model to test my new 1mm nozzle with but it should print just fine with any smaller nozzle size.

The part that sits on the bed rail is intentionally to big because I wanted to add some soft material in there (I used cardboard from an old box) to give it a tight fit and protect the bed's wood from the printed part finish.

I printed this in PLA with 5% infill, 1mm shells, no support.

The STL I uploaded is for a be frame that is approximately 3cm wide, you can make a copy of this and change the size in OnShape using this link:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/cfc7c98bfc25c656f59fac89/w/6ce60dddc0b06477bff00778/e/3d8676af667f5b1969c72073

Variable W is the width of the bed frame boards, variable B is the diameter of the bottle hole.

Designed with OnShape, sliced with Cura and printed on a Robo 3D R1+

author: Kumardebu

title: Radial low-RPM Halbach array PM Generator with serpentine coils.

description.text:
This generator is designed for our converter low-potential energy into electricity.
Also, it can be applied in wind or hydro-generators.
http://www.slideshare.net/bulgakovatanya/argenar

  1. Halbach array allows the most efficient use of the energy of the magnetic field of the permanent magnets. There is no need to put the iron disk.
    The magnetic field at the outer side of the rotor is much stronger than on the inside.
    https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Halbach_array
  2. The radial design of the magnets and windings.
    This allows for a uniform magnetic field and to increase the efficiency of the winding.
    The radial design is more efficient than axial in this case.
  3. Serpentine coil.
    This type of winding is the best compared to the three-phase winding. But serpentine coil has more difficult to assemble, but it is worth it.
  4. 3D printed parts.
    You can use any plastic materials for printing details for this generator. But for more powerful generators needed a solid filament. Otherwise, the rotor can be deformed by a powerful magnet.
    3D printing and the principle of combining radial Halbach array PM and serpentine coil allows you to build highly efficient generators (and motors) -like radial and linear.
    It is possible to make the generator for a wide range of capacities and sizes - from generators to the Internet of Things (up to 1-2W) to 5-10 kW generator for local installations. 3D printing can reduce the time and cost of construction of the entire device.

Printer:

prusa i3

Infill:

0,15

Notes:

Material ABS
Shaft 5mm,
bearing 625zz.
PM 15X5X5 mm
NdFeB N42

comments.author: zack44087

comments.text:
Diode bridges are required. Otherwise, you will get a great loss.
I advise you to make one big generator. It will be easier.
The greater the length of the magnet will be better parameters.
Use serpentine coil is optional, but in any case the diode bridges are required.
Use a Schottky diode with low forward voltage.
Magnets with metric sizes have a Canadian company.
https://www.indigo.com/magnets/rare_earth/blocks/

author: Kumardebu

description.text: mesh spere

Printer:

eos

This is a derivative. Not my original work.  
Now that is out of the way.  
Though I think this is still not printable, there are those that want to try so here is an export from the orginal STEP file by GolanHertz.   
There are two parts that are too large to be printed on most RepRap based printers. (long_connector and Base_for_Cryptex)  
It really wouldn't be hard to take this assembly and design a printable version. This makes for a good visualisation of how the Jansen Mechanism works. The original Jansen Mech uses an 3d printer unfriendly crank shaft, while this design replaces that with the offset wheels, a good step forward. Also, replace the long unprintable pins, Make a CryptexBase in pieces, make the connector pins printer friendly and make all the parts flat on one side for printing and you'd have a printable version. Simple right?  
This is not something I have time to do, on this day.

Remember if you scale any piece it won't mate properly with the others. you should scale all the pieces by the same amount if you want to print those large pieces. But that will make many parts very thin.  
Nearly all the pieces will need a good bit of support to print on an FDM printer.  
Each part name has the number needed for the assembly in the name eg 8x means "8 copies of that part".

comments.text: May I suggest the "Brabeast" if anyone is looking for an FDM printable version http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:48087http://www.thingiverse.com/thi.... But not to detract from this thing in any way.

remixed_from.author: thruit00
remixed_from.title: Mk8 Spring loaded Drive Block Replicator 1 / Duplicator 4 / FlashForge / CTC

title: Spring Drive Block Extruder for CTC Bizer (Replicator Clone) MK8 Remix for Makerbot Clone 3D Printers (FlashForge, Wanhao)

description.text:
Thing Status: Proven/Stable
I've been using this drive block for some time now, and have installed it on a few other CTC's without any problems. But then again, it was a tried and proven base model before I started messing with it...

I did however have a couple of quarrels with the MK8 Spring Block and edge of the heatbreak shaving off filament on my CTC because it wasn't properly aligned . This lead to my prints being sprinkled with filament shavings and a loaded drive gear after a few hours. To solve this I moved the location to perfectly line up with the aluminium block on the CTC and added an extra just to make life easier.

With the slot in the lever you can quickly see if your extruder gear is packed full, and also allow you to blow it free with compressed air during a print. Normally this should not be necessary, but if for any reason...

On the bottom of the block I also added a side gantry that might help to better cool the filament and drive gear, but it definitely gives an escape for any shavings to go when you clear the drive without having to remove the extruder. The lever has also been reinforced and some material transfered over from the cover (making it possible to print without needing a solid infill) as well as centered the v-groove bearing that was somewhat out of alignment.

Files are uploaded in both STL for direct printing and STP if you see the need to modify it. You can also simply download CTC_Drive_Block_Complete_LR.thing to just get to printing!

Printer:

CTC Bizer (Replicator Clone)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30

Notes:

Print with 2 shells and at minimum use ABS | Roof and floor height - 1mm | Layer height - 0.2mm | 30% infill with a linear pattern (layer height for layer strength, and a linear infill pattern is both stronger than hex and also saves your printer from unnecessary jolting) -->

See: http://my3dmatter.com/influence-infill-layer-height-pattern/

To help aid the cooling of the filament (very important when printing dual extrusion models), drill a few holes at the back of the heatsink as shown here: http://www.newmansworld.de/bilder/3D/CTC%20(13).JPG

On a side note: This website is in German (For those who don't do German, open the page in Chrome and scroll all the way down, there you can select a language with Google Translate), but it shows a pretty good list of things to do for your CTC http://www.newmansworld.de/3d-druck/tuning.html

Assembly

You may need to take a 6mm drillbit and shave off some material in the recess on the lever where it pivots on the screw. You want the screw to just bottom out and leave the movement of the lever to be "snappy" when you let go without any lateral wiggle. Resistance in the lever movement prevents the tensioner from properly gripping the filament!

You will also need to flip the drive gear so the filament doesn't run across the set screw.

Parts list:

M3 x 18mm Flat Head Cap Countersunk Hex Screw
(the screws that mount the stock CTC drive blocks are 18mm)
M3 x 8mm Flat Head Cap Countersunk Hex Screw
M3 x 6mm Flat Head Cap Countersunk Hex Screw
Compression Spring (7,5mm OD x 35,8 L) 32lbs/in spring rate
https://www.hornbach.de/shop/Druckfeder-galv-verzinkt-7-5x35-8x0-7-mm-100-Stueck/7915842/artikel.html
I cut the spring to about 26mm, but also tried it at the full length - both worked, so your choice.
Reuse the v-groove ball bearing that came with your static CTC drive block.
If you need another v-groove bearing, it's a 3x12x4mm like this one:
https://shop.stoutwind.de/Radialkugellager-mit-V-Nutprofil-V623-2Z-R3-x-R12-x-4-mm

Source of original design

I took the STL files from the Spring-Loaded Replicator 1 Drive Block (Thing:62510) and modified them using Fusion 360.

this is a work in progress

tolerance: 0,5mm.

now I'm using Repetier firmware (with laser engraver option), i slice with a program found here: http://forum.seemecnc.com/viewtopic.php?f=36&t=9773

in ramps to use the Z out as X axis, change "Stepper socket X_(STEP|DIR|ENABLE)_PIN" in repetier firmware

----------- UPDATE 12/2017 -----------
This project is closed! This structure failed plotter and milling tests, it's structure is too weak, so i decide to abandon this project and start a new one!
Thank You!

Z axis mechanism (it's very slow)
The video about my new tests

This is Sir Mi-Rhun Woo-Jung, fourth follower of Sigismund. Mi-Rhun have no problem lying and bending the rules, evidently displayed by the fact that he isn't really knighted, but he dosen't lack a strong ethical compass. Slashing away with his scimitar, Mi-Rhun prefers his enemy close.

I think this model is based on Stu Cameron's elf, that is the armour. I added the stylish moustache, which unfortunately is a bit small to print properly. I enlarged it several times to get it to work, which it only sort of does. But I don't want it any larger.

The small buckler is simply an extruded svg from Wikimedia Commons while I drew the scimitar my self in Inkscape.

You can edit the model in Tinkercad. That's currently only the character, I'll add the equipment some other way.

As have become my custom with Flatminis, I've printed this one on my oblong base. Both that one and the standard circular base is included.

This is based on the original model, but since that was only for Iphone 6, I decided to make an adjustable model that could fit almost any smart phone.

This model was designed to print in a single piece.
Please leave any feedback in the comments.

remixed_from.title: quick fit extruder for J head hot end

description.text:
this is an extruder named Loop:
  • for NEMA17 stepped motor
  • standart 50mm M4 fixation holes at the bottom
  • RichRap quick-fit compatible
  • J-head/e3d nozzle buit-in holder
    • it's mainly a variant of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28916 and Greg's Wade reloaded
    what is different then?
  • Tiltable M4 idler-screws really open (by 40°) and have a stronger nuts housing
  • filament is closer to the M8 drive bolt than olekdh version (3.7mm center-to-center)
  • oblong hole for motor positionning are wider, allowing to disangage the gear for easier assembly
  • add a support for drive screw bearing surface.
  • it's fully redesigned in Solidworks 2013
    • see instruction for more informations and changelog
    feel free to make suggestions to improve this design!

instructions
  • print the parts extruder_Loop_v1.1.stl and J-head_caps_for_extruder_Loopv1.1.stl
  • remove support material around the door axis, the drive bolt's bearing cavity and on the J-head caps.
  • print biggearmod_fixed.stl, smallgearmod_fixed.stl and jonaskuehling_gregs-wade-v3_idler-only.stl from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18379
  • assemble mechanical part (do i need to explain this?-> comment)
    • changelog
    v1.1:
  • increased Tiltable idler-screws angle from 35° to 40°
  • increased Tiltable idler-screws holes width from 4.0 to 4.3mm (to compensate bridging under-curved surface)
  • increased clearance for door support basisi
  • increased space between filament hole and drive bolt from 3.5 to 3.7mm
  • reduced quick-fit plugable ends height from 5.6 to 5.3mm
    v1.0:
  • initial release (part on pictures above)

Scan Specifications: 123D Catch on an iPhone 5S.

description.text:
This is a diferent version of an original design by ByFormica.
I did the model from scratch and made a model that wastes very little material, optimized to minimum volume and it prints just over 2 hours at 0,2mm layer height.
I have a queen there that i cought 3 days ago and she is laying eggs already, so it works like a charm.
The piece has 3 chambers in the middle wich can be filled with cotton and later impregnated with water.
Steps Are :
1) 3d print ->
2) cut acrylic to size,
3) drill 3 holes for chambers
4) glue acrylic
5) insert the queen ant through the big hole.
6) Close both exit half-holes with cotton.
7) Pour water into the holes, impregnate cotton.
8) Put a cover to block light and the queen will lay eggs in 2 to 3 days.

Troglodytes aren't normally aquatic, at least not the Pathfinder kind. But I needed one in a wetter environment, so there's fin-like extrusions on the head and interdigital webbing between the toes.. It's inspired by this beautiful piece of art by GoroliciousArt.

Famed for their skill with javelins, this troglodyte nonetheless wields a jagged, rusty sword. Maybe I should have made the hacks in the blade more prominent, but I didn't want the sword to be too weak.

You can edit the model in Tinkercad.

As have become my custom with Flatminis, I've printed this one on my oblong base. Both that one and the standard circular base is included.

title: Animusoft Humanoid Bot Mark I
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a prototype humanoid development robot platform. Our intent is to make a platform with the "function over form" mind set. Feel free to comment, change, improve or add on to our designs. These are free for everyone to use for educational and non-commercial applications. We hope to gain a good understanding of the motions that are required for a proper humanoid robot platform. We hope to mimic the human structure as much as possible in terms of motion. Upon completion we will move onto Mark 2 which would have thought for different types of actuators, components, electronics and batteries. A few disclaimers for those of you attempting to print this thing.
  • It has not been printed on our side yet - therefore - have fun
  • This is not a final version - this is Mark 1 a.k.a. v1.0 alpha
  • No thought was put in for servos, motors, muscle wire, air muscle or any other actuator
  • No thought was put in for electronics on the body
  • The only spot we thought about electronics was in the head
  • The head was designed to fit two web cameras, 4 microphones, 1 microcontroller (i.e. arduino), 1 embedded pc (i.e. raspberrypi) and a few components (i.e. gps, compass, gyro, ports)
  • The Animusoft Corporation cannot be held liable for any damages that may be incurred by working with Animusoft Bot Mark 1
    • For more information about Animusoft check out our website @ http://www.animusoft.com

description.text:
A lovely hook for the wall or ceiling.

Designed to accept whatever screws you have lying around the house, such as #10 pan head or wood screws.

Three versions for billions and billions of applications.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%, 3+ shells

Notes:

Designed for efficient printing, beauty, and strength.

Print with the long flat side on the build plate. This will align the filament strands with the direction of tension for maximum load-carrying capacity.

If you have time and enough material in the perimeters, whittle down the sharp edges with a hobby knife until they are round to the touch. Doing this will beautify your hook even more.

Not recommended for safety critical applications such as playground swing chains or anchoring ropes for window washing skyscrapers.

Please do not eat the hook. Keep away from small humans or pets which might eat it.
This is an original design. If you wish to make a commercial derivative product, please contact me here.

print_settings.Notes:: I had to rotate the .stl -90 degrees (or 270 I guess).

description.text:
The site tech for our district's high school wanted to be able to label the power cord ends in the chromebook carts. The clip is 4.8mm at the center. I modeled/test fit with the new HP chromebooks they ordered this summer.

Blank.stl is just that. Tags numbered 1-36 are in the zip file. As always, including the Fusion 360 file.
If you just want to edit the text in the Fusion 360, it's the last sketch in the timeline. Edit Feature>double-click the text and the window will pop up. You can set font, height, and the actual text.

Customizer version is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1685558

Please post made pics if you make one (or several) ;)
Likes and collects are nice and certainly appreciated, but it's a different sense of satisfaction when someone posts a made pic. TIA

Printer Brand:

Printer:

Notes:

I had to rotate the .stl -90 degrees (or 270 I guess).

Designed it in Fusion 360 (file included). Since this is the first thing I've created that I thought was well-suited for a customizer thing, I've started working with OpenSCAD to create the customizer version. Thanks to @torleif in the OpenSCAD group for getting over a big hitch I was missing.

That version will be coming soon. Just need to firm up some options.
